lines.text: My brother Dickon will be coming up to see thee.
Your brother?
Aye, thou'll like Dickon. What a one he is for growing things and the animals. Half lives on it, he does, almost like an animal himself.
I've watched thee go about the garden. There's no way in.
In where?
The secret garden. He locked the gate long years ago.
Who locked the gate?
The master. Lord Craven, thy uncle.
What do you know about it?
I know what's said. He locked the gate and buried the key, and nary's a soul been in there since.
I don't believe you. Do you know why I don't believe you? Because there isn't any gate. I've looked.
Eh, so've I.
What were you doing watching me?
I came to play with thee. My mother thought thou might be lonely.
Well, I'm not, and I don't play with any servant's brother. I never heard of anything so ridiculous. Thou can just go home.
[Dickon laughs]
I mean, you can just go home.
What's that?
A fox cub. His name's Captain.
Dickon, are you still angry with me?
When was I ever angry with thee?
Oh, good. Dickon, I've got so many secrets I'm just dying.
Thou seems most healthy.
Dickon, I need you. All you have to do is listen. What good is a secret if there's no one to tell it to?
Thou's not such a bad-looking lass, at that.
[pause]
Why, thou's blushing like a beet.
You don't even care how I won't live to grow up.
Stop it. You'll live as long as I will. You just say that to make people feel sorry for you and do what you say.
Don't you dare say that! Don't you dare say how I won't die!
Why, you're proud of it. It makes you feel important.
And Ben said he loved her, and I said, what of that? Is loving someone a reason to kill? And Ben said, how old are thee?
My father must've loved my mother very much.
I suppose we're not old enough. There must be an awful lot we don't know. I don't want to grow up.
Wait a minute. Aren't you going to dress me?
What?
Well, in India, it's the custom.
Thou cannot dress thyself?
Of course I can. It's just -
[Martha laughs]
Martha, I heard someone crying last night, as I was going to bed. I'm sure I heard someone crying.
Aye, it was the scullery maid. It was last night. She had a toothache. What a fearful row!
Mrs. Medlock said it was the wind.
Oh, she did?
I'll play with you some other time. I have to meet Dickon.
Who's Dickon?
A boy I know.
I don't like him!
You don't like anything.
Yes, I do. I want you to stay here and play with me.
